history.content:
There are many options depending on what you're interested in. I'm personally want to pursue SWE(software engineering) and interested in ML just because I think it's really cool so my plan is take:

     For SWE: CS 170, 162, 186, 161, 168

     For ML: CS 188, Stat 134/EE 126, 127, CS 189

Someone else should comment for more hardware level classes......

children.subject:
Yeah, agree with CS188, Data 100, and Stat 140 (over Stat 134, if you've taken Data 8).

161 and 186 are cool too and a good chance to flex your Python scripting and Java SWE muscles, respectively.

Would recommend taking more theory-heavy classes like 170/189 after EE16A/B and potentially another upper level mathy course (Stat 134/140, EECS 126/127, etc.)

history.content:
The advice I usually give at advising sessions since it is completely reasonable to feel without guidance given so many courses, and the explicit prereqs not really telling you what to take in which order.

1) Finish the lower-division first. The six courses are required for everyone for a reason. This will also give you a taste of the spirit of things to come. 

2) Choose an appropriate entry-level upper-div for the area that you are interested in.

Software engineering: 162 

Circuits: 105 or 151

Devices: 130

"Mathy Side": 170, 126, or 127. (Can also include 120 on this list depending...)

Each of these should pick up where the relevant lower-divs left off, and continue to build both maturity and technical foundations. You will work hard --- which is a good thing.

Which one you pick first depends on what you liked best within the lower-div courses. e.g. Did you like 61B's graph algorithms? Did you enjoy the analysis of stable matching in 70? Did you like the DFT in 16B? If so, go for 170.... Did you like the probability parts of 70? Want to eventually understand ML and/or AI? Go for 126.... Did you really like all the obviously machine-learning parts of 16A and 16B? Go for 127. Did you like the analog circuits parts of 16A and 16B? Go for 105. Did you like the digital parts of 61C and 16B? Go for 151. Did you like 61C and C? Go for 162. Did you like the spirit of your Physics and Chemistry classes, and the connections between the physical and electronic worlds teased in 16A and 16B? Go for 130. Did you really like the concept of frequency domain and the control and DFT sections in 16B? Go for 120.

3) After the first round of core upper-divs, you can go deeper in areas you like while continuing to flesh out your breadth within the department by taking other core upper-divs. For each of the 4 broad areas above, there are additional courses that flesh the area out for you beyond the purposefully narrow list of entry-level upper-divs listed above.

I'm about to declare CS and I was wondering how I should make a decision regarding which upper division CS classes to take when I'm still exploring my interests. 

I've looked around online for recommendations on good classes to take first, but all I can find is the descriptions of what each CS class is about.

Do you guys have any recommendations for general CS upper divs?

Is there a list of most common or most popular CS upper divs? I suppose I could look at the class sizes to make sure I'm not accidentally enrolling in some niche class that I thought I would like.

Most people I've talked to mention classes like CS 170 and CS 188. Is this true, and are there more like these?
history.subject: Common Beginning Upper Division Classes
